metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of automatic meteorological observations at the Dayekou Maliantan grassland station in the Dayekou watershed from Nov to Dec, 2007
metadata.description:
The dataset of automatic meteorological observations was obtained at the Dayekou Maliantan grassland station (E100°18′/N38°33′, 2817m) from Nov. 2, 2007 to  Dec. 31, 2009. The experimental area with a flat and open terrain was slightly sloping from southeast to northwest. The landscape was mainly grassland, with vegetation 0.2-0.5m high.
     Observation items were multilayer gradient (2m and 10m) of the wind speed, the air temperature and air humidity, the air pressure, precipitation, four components of radiation, the multilayer soil temperature (5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, and 120cm), soil moisture (5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, and 120cm), and soil heat flux (5cm & 15cm). 
     The raw data were level0 and the data after basic processes were level1, in which ambiguous ones were marked; the data after strict quality control were defined as Level2. The data files were named as follows: station+datalevel+AMS+datadate. Level2 or above were strongly recommended to domestic users. As for detailed information, please refer to Meteorological and Hydrological Flux Data Guide.

background: Land surface heat fluxes are essential measures of the strengths of land-atmosphere interactions involving energy, heat and water. Correct parameterization of these fluxes in climate models is critical. Despite their importance, state-of-the-art observation techniques cannot provide representative areal averages of these fluxes comparable to the model grid. These alternative approaches use (satellite) observables of the land surface conditions.
research objective: In this study, the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm was evaluated in a cold and arid environment, using land surface parameters derived from Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) data.
methods: Field observations and estimates from SEBS were compared in terms of net radiation flux (Rn), soil heat flux (G0), sensible heat flux (H) and latent heat flux (λE) over a heterogeneous land surface. As a case study, this methodology was applied to the experimental area of the Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (W A TER) project, located on the mid-to-upstream sections of the Heihe River in northwest China. ASTER data acquired between 3 May and 4 June 2008, under clear-sky conditions were used to determine the surface fluxes. Ground-based measurements of land surface heat fluxes were compared with values derived from the ASTER data.
dataset: ASTER data acquired between 3 May and 4 June 2008, under clear-sky conditions were used to determine the surface fluxes.
findings: The results showed the following: The derived net radiation flux over the study area was very close to the field measurements. The latent heat flux is obtained by calculations involving the evaporative fraction, and these calculations are the essence of SEBS. On the basis of this particular study, SEBS can be used to estimate turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy in areas where there is partial vegetation cover.

background: The near-surface atmospheric elements including air temperature, pressure, relative humility, wind, precipitation and radiation are called forcing data to drive hydrological, land surface, and ecological models. Coupling or use of the General Circulation Model (GCM) output to drive the land surface model is an important source of forcing data for large-scale land surface models, however the spatial and temporal resolution can not meet the requirements of a regional scale land surface model and its coarse resolution ignored regional environmental impact assessment. Thus, a regional scale land surface model or land surface data assimilation system needs forcing data with a higher temporal-spatial resolution. Therefore, downscaling GCM output is necessary in order to prepare for a long series of high spatial and temporal resolution forcing data for regional scale or basin-scale land surface, hydrological and ecological simulation and assimilation. Downscaling is a method of obtaining high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution GCMs. Dynamic downscaling uses large scale climatic background information to establish higher resolution meteorological distribution fields by GCMs. Regional climate model is considered to be an effective dynamic downscaling method to derive high-resolution local climate information. The model’s physical meaning is clear, it is built on the nonlinear interaction between large scale and regional scale, and can distinguish local features characterized by local topography, vegetation cover and soil hydrological processes, and can be used anywhere independent of observation data with an improved description of local features.
research objective: In order to do the validation of WRF model on simulating forcing data for the Heihe River Basin, daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of CMA (China Meteorological Administration) and hourly meteorological observation data from seven sites of WATER (Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research) are used to compare with WRF simulations, with a time range of a whole year for 2008. Thus, the validation accuracy of forcing data from RCM is important before input to drive the land surface model.
methods: The model was validated at 15 surface meteorological stations maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and seven observation-strengthened stations setup by WATER project. In this study, WRF is used for downscaling of weather and climate ranging from one kilometer to thousands of kilometers and used for deriving meteorological parameters required for hydrological models. For this study, two way nested computational domains of 41×55×28 and 101×121×28 grid points and horizontal resolutions of 25 km and 5 km, respectively, have been set. The model is initialized by real boundary conditions using NCAR-NCEP’s Final Analysis (FNL) data (NCEP-DSS083.2, 2009) having a resolution of 1°×1° (111 km×111 km).
dataset: Daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of CMA (China Meteorological Administration) and hourly meteorological observation data from seven sites of WATER (Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research) are used to compare with WRF simulations, with a time range of a whole year for 2008. The model was validated at 15 surface meteorological stations maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and seven observation-strengthened stations setup by WATER project. Data from CMA stations are used for daily validation; the WATER’s are for hourly validation. All CMA data in 2008 are used for comparison, the time span of WATER’s are listed in Table 2.
findings: Results show that the average MBE (Mean Bias Error) of daily 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, 2-m relative humidity and 10-m wind speed were −0.19 °C, −4.49 hPa, 4.08% and 0.92 m/s, the average RMSE (Root Mean Square Error) of them were 2.11 °C, 5.37 hPa, 9.55% and 1.73 m/s, and the average R (correlation coefficient) of them were 0.99, 0.98, 0.80 and 0.55, respectively. The average MBE of hourly 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, 2-m relative humidity, 10-m wind speed, downward shortwave radiation and downward longwave were −0.16 °C, −6.62 hPa, −5.14%, 0.26 m/s, 33.0 W/m2 and −6.44 W/m2, the average RMSE of them were 2.62 °C, 17.10 hPa, 20.71%, 2.46 m/s, 152.9 W/m2 and 53.5 W/m2, and the average R of them were 0.96, 0.97, 0.70, 0.26, 0.91 and 0.60, respectively. Thus, the following conclusions were obtained: (1) regardless of daily or hourly validation, WRF model simulations of 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure and relative humidity are more reliable, especially for 2-m surface air temperature and surface pressure, the values of MBE were small and R were more than 0.96; (2) the WRF simulating downward shortwave radiation was relatively good, the average R between WRF simulation and hourly observation data was above 0.9, and the average R of downward longwave radiation was 0.6; (3) both wind speed and rainfall simulated from WRF model did not agree well with observation data.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure atmospheric conditions and soil parameters in a grassland environment?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of an automatic meteorological station to measure atmospheric wind, temperature, humidity gradients, pressure, precipitation, radiation components, multi-layer soil temperature, soil moisture, and soil heat flux at specific depths in a grassland environment. This method was employed at a station in the Da Ye Kou Ma Lian Tan grassland, located in the upper reaches of the Heihe River basin.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset used to validate climate model simulations in a regional scale study?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for validation of climate model simulations is the daily meteorological observation data from 15 stations of the China Meteorological Administration and hourly observation data from seven sites of the Watershed Airborne Telemetry Experimental Research project. These data were used to validate the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model simulations for the Heihe River Basin over the year 2008.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how satellite data can be integrated with field observations to study land surface heat fluxes?
Example.Answer: An example of integrating satellite data with field observations is the evaluation of the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm using land surface parameters derived from Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) data. This approach was applied to the Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research project area, where ASTER data under clear-sky conditions were used alongside ground-based measurements to determine surface fluxes such as net radiation, soil heat, sensible heat, and latent heat fluxes.

Definition.Question: What does 'downscaling' refer to in the context of obtaining high-resolution climate data for regional models?
Definition.Answer: Downscaling refers to a method used to obtain high-resolution climate or climate change information from relatively coarse-resolution GCMs. It involves establishing higher resolution meteorological distribution fields by using large-scale climatic background information, which is particularly useful for regional scale or basin-scale land surface, hydrological, and ecological simulation and assimilation.

Definition.Question: How is 'Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS)' used to estimate land surface heat fluxes in a cold and arid environment?
Definition.Answer: The Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) is used to estimate land surface heat fluxes by evaluating the land surface parameters derived from satellite data, such as ASTER. SEBS calculates turbulent heat fluxes, like net radiation, soil heat, sensible heat, and latent heat fluxes, and is especially useful in areas with partial vegetation cover, as demonstrated over the mid-to-upstream sections of the Heihe River.

Definition.Question: What does 'forcing data' mean in the context of driving hydrological and land surface models?
Definition.Answer: Forcing data refers to the near-surface atmospheric elements, including air temperature, pressure, relative humidity, wind, precipitation, and radiation, which are used to drive hydrological, land surface, and ecological models. These data are crucial in coupling with or using the output from General Circulation Models to simulate regional scale land surface models.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of satellite observable data in cold and arid environments enhance the accuracy of land surface heat flux estimations?
Interpretation.Answer: Satellite observables can provide representative areal averages of land surface conditions that are difficult to obtain through traditional field observations. These data, when integrated into algorithms like the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS), can improve the estimation of net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux with acceptable accuracy, especially in areas with partial vegetation cover.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the interaction between large-scale climatic processes and localized environmental features from the use of dynamic downscaling in regional climate modeling?
Interpretation.Answer: Dynamic downscaling leverages large-scale climatic information to derive high-resolution local climate data, which allows for a more detailed understanding of nonlinear interactions between large-scale and regional-scale processes. This method distinguishes local features influenced by topography, vegetation cover, and soil hydrological processes, leading to enhanced local climate modeling and environmental impact assessments.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the validation of atmospheric model simulations against ground-based observation data inform improvements in regional climate models?
Interpretation.Answer: Validation against ground-based data helps identify the strengths and weaknesses of model simulations, such as the accuracy of 2-m surface temperature, surface pressure, and relative humidity predictions. It highlights areas where models perform well, like simulating downward shortwave radiation, and areas needing improvement, such as wind speed and rainfall estimates. This feedback can be used to refine model parameters, improve simulation algorithms, and enhance the reliability of regional climate models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of obtaining representative areal averages of land surface heat fluxes in climate models, especially in cold and arid environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: State-of-the-art observation techniques cannot provide representative areal averages of land surface heat fluxes comparable to the model grid, particularly in cold and arid environments. This challenge arises due to the heterogeneous nature of land surface conditions and the limitations in parameterizing these fluxes accurately in climate models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for downscaling General Circulation Model outputs to drive regional scale land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial and temporal resolution of General Circulation Model outputs cannot meet the requirements of a regional scale land surface model. Their coarse resolution ignores regional environmental impacts, necessitating downscaling to provide high spatial and temporal resolution forcing data required for accurate regional scale or basin-scale simulations and assessments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the discrepancy between WRF model simulations and observation data for wind speed and rainfall, and how does it impact the validation process?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The discrepancy between WRF model simulations and observation data for wind speed and rainfall arises because the model simulations do not agree well with the observed data. This impacts the validation process as it leads to less reliable simulations for these variables, highlighting the need for further refinement in the model's parameterizations and understanding of local meteorological processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in ensuring the accuracy and quality control of meteorological data collected from automated weather stations in a grassland setting?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data is initially collected as raw (0-level) output from the automated weather stations. Thereafter, any suspected problematic data is flagged as 1-level without deletion. A further processing step involves organizing the data into a uniform 30-minute sampling period and applying quality control measures to produce 2-level data, which is recommended for general use.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are land surface parameters derived from satellite data to assess surface energy balance in a cold and arid environment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the described research approach, the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm is utilized to evaluate land surface parameters derived from Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) data. These parameters are used to estimate net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux over a heterogeneous land surface.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable researchers to ensure the quality control of meteorological data collected in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: The data collected from the automatic meteorological station is organized into various levels, with level 2 data undergoing quality control and being organized into 30-minute sampling periods. This ensures that the data is reliable and suitable for general use.

Enablement.Question: What conditions facilitate the effective implementation of downscaling techniques for high-resolution climate data in regional models?
Enablement.Answer: The use of regional climate models like WRF, which are initialized with real boundary conditions from larger datasets such as NCAR-NCEP’s Final Analysis, enables downscaling. These models use dynamic downscaling to derive high-resolution local climate information, taking into account local topography, vegetation, and soil processes.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of satellite data support the estimation of land surface heat fluxes in regions with partial vegetation cover?
Enablement.Answer: Satellite data, such as ASTER data, is used to derive land surface parameters that are essential for algorithms like the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS). This integration allows for the estimation of turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy by using calculations involving the evaporative fraction, which is crucial in areas with partial vegetation cover.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in using existing data collection methods to obtain representative areal averages of land surface heat fluxes in a heterogeneous landscape?
Expectation.Answer: Existing observation techniques may not provide areal averages comparable to the model grid due to the variability and heterogeneity of the landscape, which affects the accuracy of parameterization in climate models.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a need to prioritize certain data collection methods over others for accurately estimating turbulent heat fluxes in areas with partial vegetation cover?
Expectation.Answer: Certain methods, such as the SEBS algorithm, may provide acceptable accuracy by utilizing satellite-derived land surface parameters, which can be particularly useful in areas with partial vegetation cover where traditional ground-based observations may be limited.

Judgmental.Question: How might the integration of satellite observables enhance the reliability of land surface heat flux estimates in heterogeneous terrains?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of satellite observables, such as those from the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER), can enhance the reliability of land surface heat flux estimates by providing representative areal averages that complement field observations. These satellite-derived parameters allow for improved parameterization in models like SEBS, making it possible to estimate turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy in partially vegetated areas.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can quality control measures be effectively implemented in meteorological data to ensure its utility for hydrological and ecological modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: Quality control measures can be effectively implemented by organizing data into various levels, such as the 0-level raw data, 1-level data with flagged anomalies, and 2-level data that undergoes 30-minute sampling and quality checks. This structured approach ensures that researchers and models utilize data that is not only accurate but also reliable, thereby enhancing its utility for hydrological and ecological modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection techniques can ensure the accuracy of soil moisture measurements at different depths in a typical grassland environment.
Assertion.Answer: In the field of Heihe River studies, soil moisture is measured at multiple depths (5cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, and 120cm) using ground-based instruments. These measurements are part of a comprehensive set of meteorological observations that include atmospheric and soil parameters. Data accuracy is ensured through a systematic approach involving initial data collection (0 level), preliminary data organization with potential issues flagged (1 level), and quality-controlled data at a uniform sampling interval (2 level).

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how remote sensing data is integrated with field observations to evaluate heat fluxes in a heterogeneous land surface.
Assertion.Answer: In the studies mentioned, remote sensing data from the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) is used alongside field observations to evaluate heat fluxes. The Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm is employed to derive surface fluxes such as net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux, which are then compared to ground-based measurements to ensure consistency and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for obtaining high-resolution meteorological parameters required for hydrological models and their implications for regional climate modeling.
Request/Directive.Answer: High-resolution meteorological parameters are crucial for hydrological models and are often obtained through downscaling methods. For regional climate modeling, dynamic downscaling is employed, utilizing large-scale climatic information from General Circulation Models (GCMs) to establish higher resolution meteorological fields. This method considers local topography, vegetation, and soil processes. The Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model is an example used for downscaling in the Heihe River Basin, validated against data from meteorological observation stations. It provides the necessary temporal and spatial resolution for regional assessments.
